title: 108_hr3978
content: The Act may be cited as the "Designation of Foreign Terrorist Organizations Reform Act". This Act pertains to the designation of foreign terrorist organizations. The "Designation of Foreign Terrorist Organizations Reform Act" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding the period of designation for foreign terrorist organizations. The Secretary will review the designation based on specific procedures. The "Designation of Foreign Terrorist Organizations Reform Act" allows designated organizations to file a petition for revocation within a specified period after the designation is made. The "Designation of Foreign Terrorist Organizations Reform Act" allows designated organizations to file a petition for revocation within 2 years of a determination made on a previous petition, requiring evidence of changed circumstances. The Secretary must make a determination on a revocation petition within 180 days, and classified information can be considered but not disclosed if classified. The Secretary must make a determination on a revocation petition within 180 days, and classified information can be considered but not disclosed except to a court ex parte and in camera for judicial review. The determination made by the Secretary must be published in the Federal Register, and any revocation shall be done in accordance with specified procedures. Additionally, if no review of designation occurs within a 4-year period, other review processes may be initiated. If no review occurs within a 4-year period, the Secretary will review the designation of a foreign terrorist organization to consider revocation. If a petition for revocation is not responded to, a review will be conducted following established procedures. The results of the review and procedures are not subject to further review. The Secretary may amend a designation under this subsection if the organization has changed its name, adopted a new alias, or reconstituted itself under a different name. The results of the review and procedures are not subject to further court review. The organization can be amended under this subsection if it has changed its name, adopted a new alias, or reconstituted itself under a different name. The amendments are effective upon publication in the Federal Register, with relevant information supporting the changes included in the administrative record. Classified information may be considered in the amendment process. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for disclosure of classified information to a court for judicial review. Technical and conforming amendments are made to subsection (a) of Section 219. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for disclosure of classified information to a court for judicial review. Amendments are made to subsection (c) regarding the redesignation and review process. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow designated organizations to seek judicial review for designation, amended designation, or determination in response to a petition for revocation. Amendments are made to various paragraphs to include these provisions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include all redesignations made prior to the date of enactment of this Act for the term "designation" in section 219. Redesignations shall remain effective until revoked as specified in section 219(a). SEC. 3. Inclusion in annual Department of State country reports on terrorism of information on terrorist groups seeking weapons of mass destruction and designated foreign terrorist organizations. The amendment to Section 140 of the Foreign Relations Authorization Act includes reporting on terrorist groups seeking weapons of mass destruction and designated foreign terrorist organizations. The amendment includes providing weapons of mass destruction or assistance to terrorists, and efforts by terrorist groups to obtain such weapons. The effective date for these amendments is the first report under section 140 of the Foreign Relations Authorization Act. The amendment includes prohibiting the provision of weapons of mass destruction or aid to terrorists, and terrorist groups' attempts to acquire such weapons.
